title: Onboarding: Counts of fetched data does not match the account

milestone.description:
## Messaging & Communities team 

**1. Continue to fix bugs and stabilise chat and communities functionality as top priority**

**2. Finish anything that wasn't completed in the previous 0.17 cycle**

**3. Complete work on profile showcase**

**4. Status Communities / Discord bridge**
- Community admin screens to make it easier for a Community Owner to deploy a bridge (design required)

**5.  IPFS service for community minted NFTs and other binary community assets**

- In order for NFT tokens minted in our UI to be correctly displayed with all metadata on OpenSea, their assets need to be stored in IPFS (because IPFS is supported by OpenSea)

- Will work something like this: IPFS pinning server is integrated into Status Desktop. When a community mints a NFT, the associated assets are IPFS pinned by the community control node.  The community control node then sends a 'user invisible message' to all other community members via Waku, and the Status Desktop installs of all community members then fetch the NFT assets and pin them as well.  This means that every member of a community that is running Status Desktop will always be 'IPFS pinning' all assets related to the community, so that as long as one community member that uses Status Desktop is online, the assets are guaranteed to be available via IPFS.

- Use a similar scheme to the above could be used for other community assets (that are not related to token minting) in the future like: Community banner image, community icon, community description, etc...

- Use a similar scheme to the above could be used for status user data in the future.  Status users pin assets related to their profile (banner image, avatar, showcase contents) using IPFS, and all of the user's mutual contacts also pin that user's profile data.  Must incorporate a setting so that users can opt-out of pinning their mutual contact's profile data.

**6. Chat functionality enhancements**
- Introduce @channel as a new type of global @ mention.  This @ mention only @ mention's everyone who has posted a message in a channel in the last 30 days 
- optional service to once a month auto-kick all members who haven't been online for between 30 and 60 days (e.g. auto-kick members whose profile information like Name, Avatar, etc... can no longer be fetched).  Design still required

 

## Wallet Team

**1. Implement on WalletConnect UI and associated functionality**

**2. Start work on total balance graphs for 'All accounts' and each individual account and all graph functionality**

**2. Complete support for KeycardPro via USB**
- Requires design
- Support for ERC-4527 will be the next task in this workstream after KPro USB support is complete

**4. Advanced transaction signing**

**5. QR scanner**
- Needed for private key transfer
- Ethereum key QRs (send modal triggered)
- User Share URL in a QR (opens user profile dialogue) 
- Community and Channel inside Community URL in QRs (takes user to Community or Channel in Community)

**6. Database re-encryption flows**

body:
# Bug Report

## Description

After restoring from seed phrase the user is presented with a count of how many items have been synced. The following counts were wrong:

- 10 contacts were shown but the account had 18
- 24 communities are shown but the account only has 13 active

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/50769329/232920869-b30cd463-f1cc-495d-86f3-bb50b359cbc2.png)

## Steps to reproduce

Take note of how many contacts and communities are expected to be fetched during a restore
With a fresh install, restore the account from seed phrase and check the counts of data shown to be fetched

#### Expected behavior

Counts of contacts and communities before a restore match those after a restore.

#### Actual behavior

Counts do not match

### Additional Information

- Status desktop version: https://ci.status.im/job/status-desktop/job/branches/job/macos/job/aarch64/job/package/job/PR-10292/3/ (found during #10292 )
- Operating System: Mac
@glitchminer cannot reproduce this one, could you please double check and close if not?

Hi @alexandraB99 , I was able to reproduce this.

| item                                   | fetched count | shown after login|
| --- | --- | --- |
| contacts                            | 7                      | 5                           |
| community memberships| 14                     |9                           |

I think it may be related to this bug on retrieving data from waku in general https://github.com/status-im/status-desktop/issues/12797

> I can reproduce this and there are 2 aspects to clarify:
> 
> 1. The number of contacts we see in the profile fetching view is not the number of mutual contacts that's being fetched. It's the number of backup messages we expect to process, each one containing max. 20 contacts.
> 2. The number of communities in the profile fetching view represents the active communities + deleted communities.
> 
> @glitchminer In your case the app probably fetched ~7*20 contacts, 9 active communities, 5 deleted communities.
> 
> @benjthayer Is the current behaviour the expected one? Same as @glitchminer, I was expecting to see a parity between the numbers presented in the profile fetching view and the data presented in the app after the sync was finished.

I would also expect for the profile fetching view to tally with the numbers inside the app. If the numbers the user sees in the fetch flow are less, the user will think there has been an issue with the fetching of data. Similarly if the numbers are more - they may think the fetch is inaccurate or reflective of a less recent point in time.

> > I can reproduce this and there are 2 aspects to clarify:
> > 
> > 1. The number of contacts we see in the profile fetching view is not the number of mutual contacts that's being fetched. It's the number of backup messages we expect to process, each one containing max. 20 contacts.
> > 2. The number of communities in the profile fetching view represents the active communities + deleted communities.
> > 
> > @glitchminer In your case the app probably fetched ~7*20 contacts, 9 active communities, 5 deleted communities.
> > @benjthayer Is the current behaviour the expected one? Same as @glitchminer, I was expecting to see a parity between the numbers presented in the profile fetching view and the data presented in the app after the sync was finished.
> 
> I would also expect for the profile fetching view to tally with the numbers inside the app. If the numbers the user sees in the fetch flow are less, the user will think there has been an issue with the fetching of data. Similarly if the numbers are more - they may think the fetch is inaccurate or reflective of a less recent point in time.

@jrainville @saledjenic Could you please confirm if we need to backup the deleted communities and all the imported contacts as well? (as opposed to importing only the active communities and contacts that would end up being visible in the client)

If we actually need all the data, showing only the progress for the active communities and contacts only would be misleading as well. We could easily end up showing in the UI that the sync process is completed, but there's still lots of data to be imported.
@benjthayer In this case, WDYT of showing the progress in percentage instead of count numbers?

@alexjba @benjthayer requirements for this feature are set like we're using a central server, forgetting that we're operating in a decentralized environment.

> Could you please confirm if we need to backup the deleted communities and all the imported contacts as well?

A general answer is... that depends on what level of accuracy we want to achieve. 
Yes, we need all those info. 

> If we actually need all the data, showing only the progress for the active communities and contacts only would be misleading as well.

Well, showing percentage could be a better option than, the example given above, where the fetching data screen shows 7 batches of fetched contacts (means there are 121-140 fetched contacts since each batch contains up to 20 contacts, but the first 6 batches are full and the last one 7th can have 1 - 20 contacts, fyi backed up contacts refer to any contact that user has interacted with in the past, regardless it is an active, deleted, blocked, pending contact now or not), but after login, there are only 5 contacts (not 5 batches times 20 contacts, but only 5) looks pretty incorrect from the user's point of view.

But if we display that in percentage, the user would see that the progress bar is being fulfilled incrementally with the step of (100/7 ≈ 14.3), and will be able to figure out only if all contacts are fetch or not, but won't know anything about the number of fetched contacts that he can compare with the number of contacts he sees in the app after login.
Moving to 0.18. @benjthayer @John-44 this issue needs design

Perhaps there is a distinction to be made on what we are actually fetching vs what the user is expecting to see in order to make a decision on whether to proceed with that profile or create a new one. The info I'm most concerned with as a user is how many mutual contacts and how many current community memberships etc. have been fetched so I know how complete the profile will be. 

Once we have all of the data, are we able to parse it in order to present figures that are more in line with what the user might expect to see? If so, we could show just the progress bars without the numbers - then at the end of the 2mins, if possible, we could filter the fetched data down to what the user would expect - ie how many mutual contacts, how many current community memberships etc.

How this is handled on mobile for reference incase this is easier to achieve (general progress screen (this could just as easily be the progress bars without the numbers) and a tally of what could and couldn't be fetched):
https://www.figma.com/file/o4qG1bnFyuyFOvHQVGgeFY/Onboarding-for-Mobile?type=design&node-id=3172-340624&mode=design&t=qiwwrSVC6PYRJnnj-4

@saledjenic @John-44 @alexjba
